metadata.case_name: Petitioners in Writ Petitions Nos. 289 to 295 of 1971 v. State of Manipur

facts.text: Seven petitioners challenge orders of detention dated January 31, 1971 passed by District Magistrate, Manipur Central under sub-s. (2) of s. 3 read with sub-s. (1) of the Orissa Preventive Detention Act, 1970 as extended to Manipur, with a view to preventing them from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.
Petitioners taken into custody and detained following the orders; grounds of detention furnished on the same day as required by s. 7(1) of the Act.
Prof. Nandlal Sharma also detained along with petitioners; his order of detention later revoked by Lt. Governor and released.

Petitioners in WP Nos. 289, 290, 291, 295 are M.A. in Political Science or Education, Professors in colleges in Moirang or Imphal; petitioner in WP 294 holds M.Sc., B.Ed., Assistant Head Master in High School, Imphal; petitioners in WP 292, 293 claim to be social workers.
District Magistrate made report to Administrator under s. 3(3); Administrator approved orders on February 10, 1971 under s. 3(3) and communicated to detenus.
Petitioners made joint representation on March 1, 1971 raising grounds against detention and refuting allegations; received by Government on March 3, 1971.
Administrator considered and rejected representation on March 20, 1971; petitioners informed on March 22, 1971.
Cases referred to Advisory Board on February 16, 1971 under s.9; Board considered and reported on April 18, 1971 that detention justified.

Petitioners are active members of Pan Manipuri Youth League, over-ground organisation of under-ground insurgents; publishing matters in books/pamphlets to create distrust, hatred, disaffection; holding secret meetings, inciting students to violence.

Ground No. 4: Petitioners and leaders held secret meeting Dec 13, 1970 (7-9 PM) to boycott Republic Day Jan 26, 1971 and disrupt by violence; another meeting Dec 16, 1970 (6-10:30 PM) confirmed decision, incite students/public, create panic/disorder; violent acts committed as consequence.
Prof. Nandlal Sharma arrested Dec 4, 1970 in Case No. 427/9/1970 under ss.124A/153A IPC, in jail till released on bail Dec 18, 1970.
Petitioners claim matters in grounds false; they wrote articles for improving lot of Manipur people, recognition of aspirations.
Enquiries sought from Jail authorities via S.D. Headquarters re Nandlal Sharma; Jailor letter dated March 18, 1971 confirming Sharma in jail Dec 4-18, 1970.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was inordinate unexplained delay of 17 days in disposing of petitioners' representation violating Art. 22(5) of Constitution
Whether grounds of detention are vague and devoid of particulars
Validity of detention orders under Orissa Preventive Detention Act, 1970

petitioner_arguments.text: Matters in grounds of detention absolutely false; petitioners educated persons writing articles for improving lot of Manipur people and recognition of aspirations.
Grounds of detention vague, impossible to make effective representation.
Inordinate delay of 17 days (or 20/46 days) by Administrator in disposing representation violates Art. 22(5); information re Sharma easily available from nearby Jailor.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioners active in Pan Manipuri Youth League; publishing inflammatory material, secret meetings with specifics of date/time/place, inciting students to violence; grounds not vague as petitioners refuted in detail and could seek particulars.
No delay in considering representation; enquiries from Jail via S.D. Headquarters re Sharma took time, Jailor letter March 18, 1971; explained in counter-affidavit.
Detention to prevent activities prejudicial to public order.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3(2) read with s.3(1) Orissa Preventive Detention Act, 1970

court_reasoning.text: 17-day gap from March 3 (receipt) to March 20 (rejection) is unexplained delay; no details of steps taken, no affidavits from S.D.C./Jailor, Jailor letter lacks reference to specific enquiry; violates Art.22(5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unexplained delay of 17 days sufficient to invalidate detention.

court_reasoning.text: Prima facie, grounds not vague or devoid of particulars; materials exist for detention; but unnecessary to examine further due to delay.
Sharma in jail Dec 4-18, 1970 per admission, could not attend meetings Dec 13/16 alleged in ground 4; time to verify this info minimal, does not justify 17 days.
Art.22(5) mandates expeditious consideration of representation independent of Advisory Board; relies on precedents holding unexplained delay vitiates detention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dual obligation under Art.22(5); delay loses purpose/meaning of earliest opportunity.

holdings.text: Unexplained delay of 17 days in disposing representation violates Art.22(5), rendering detention orders illegal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Durga Show etc. v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.citation: Writ Petition Nos. 198, 205, and 206 of 1969 decided on Sept. 2,1969
precedents_cited.relevance: Unexplained delay of 16 days in considering representation violates Art.22(5); must consider expeditiously independent of Advisory Board.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khairul Haque v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.citation: Writ Petition No. 246 of 1969 decided on Sept. 10, 1969
precedents_cited.relevance: Dual obligation under Art.22(5): consider representation expeditiously; delay defeats purpose.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prabhakar Shankar Dhuri v. Sh. S. G. Pradhan and others
precedents_cited.citation: Writ Petition No. 514 of 1970 decided on December 18, 1970
precedents_cited.relevance: Unexplained delay in considering representation violates Art.22(5), entitling release.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Appropriate authority bound to consider representation expeditiously; four principles on handling representations; unexplained delay unconstitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Preventive Detention Act, 1970
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention orders, furnishing grounds, approval, reference to Advisory Board.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writs of habeas corpus; right to expeditious consideration of representation against detention.

outcome.summary: Detention orders struck down due to unexplained 17-day delay in disposing joint representation, violating Art.22(5); petitioners entitled to release from custody.
outcome.relief_granted: Directions to release petitioners from custody via writ of habeas corpus.

key_quotes.text: We are of the opinion that the contention of Mr. Manchanda that there has been a delay in the State in passing orders on the representation made by the petitioners and that the said delay has not been properly explained by the State, has, in the circumstances of this case, to be accepted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on unexplained delay leading to quashing detention.

key_quotes.text: If that is so, without anything more, that circumstance by itself is a sufficient ground for holding that the orders of detention of the petitioners are illegal and they are entitled to be released.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding on effect of delay under Art.22(5).

key_quotes.text: The fact that Art. 22(5) enjoins upon the detaining authority to afford to the detenu the earliest opportunity to make a representation must implicitly mean that such representation must, when made, be considered and disposed of as expeditiously as possible.
key_quotes.speaker: court
